title: 103_hr5005
content: The Act may be cited as the "Territorial Consultation and Notification Act of 1994". The Congress has plenary authority over US territories, including determining status. The President and executive branch should consult Congress on territorial matters. Congress must promote self-government for territories based on self-determination principles. Regular voter input on political status is crucial. In the 1993 plebiscite, Puerto Rican voters rejected their current territorial status and supported significant changes in the political relationship with the United States. Limited self-government has been authorized for US territories, and all residents are native-born US citizens. The United Nations declared the 1990s as the "Decade to Eradicate Colonialism." In the 1993 plebiscite, Puerto Rican voters rejected their current territorial status and supported significant changes in the political and legal relationship between the United States and Puerto Rico. SEC. 3. REFERENDUMS ON TERRITORIAL STATUS. Territories of the United States must hold referendums on territorial status every five years. The Governor must report the results to Congress within 30 days, and committees may make recommendations for changes to laws within 180 days. The President must develop and report plans to Congress within one year after a vote on territorial status changes in the United States. The President must report annually to Congress on policy and regulatory matters affecting United States territories. Regulations impacting territories cannot take effect until 90 days after being submitted to Congress. The United States Representative to the United Nations must report on issues related to US territories. Within 180 days of enactment, the US Representative to the UN must report to Congress on issues concerning US territories in the past two years and upcoming year. The term "United States territories" includes Puerto Rico, Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, Guam, and the Virgin Islands.
